conversation_summary: Melbourne night hums with coffee-rain exhaust. Inside the warmly lit restaurant three chairs, not four; the empty seat throbs. A copper pot steams “BOILING WATER” across shifting menus. After cake swallows itself, Paris’s hatchback smells of salt; headlights smear the fog. On the beach a phone’s torch ring glows, joint smoke drifts, Harry’s eyes pulse red traffic-light. Mid-laugh, a brass plaque rises from sand like a surfacing tooth; Dad appears, cradling the still-boiling pot, offering liquid that tastes of future tears. Waves applaud. The fourth chair, the unused cup, the plaque—three holes the ocean keeps trying to fill.
